Summary Heading: Dorm-style cottage private room 38A: room with a view and private entrance!
Summary: I was able to snag a 1-night reservation for a private room in a shared dorm-style cottage. I stayed in 38A, which can accommodate 3 people. One single twin bed, with the other 2 beds as bunk beds. There were 2 small side tables and one dresser. There was a ceiling fan and two small lamps. There are 2 large windows that face the ocean. There are 2 entrances to room 38A, one door from within the cottage, and the other entrance on the side of the cottage where one can easily access the deck.  Cottage 38 had beautiful views from the kitchen and on each side deck.  My only concern is that it gets very dark at night inside the cottage, and as a solo female traveler, it is a priority for me to feel safe. If I were ever to reserve a room in 38 again, I would not choose room A or B as
Room tip: If only staying 1-night, bring food to eat at the cottage itself to maximize your time enjoying...

Summary: Yes, the location is great. Yes, the cottages are somewhat shabby. We stayed in unit 29 - still combined as one unit due to the pandemic that is nowhere near over. (One staff member told me they thought this combining would end soon, and the unit would be rented out as 29A and 29B again). Note, when I got lucky and got a reservation, it said premium cottage 2-29. At first we thought we got cottage 2, but it was 29.   Things of note:  1. We are a family of 4 and this cottage can sleep 10. There were tons of beds we did not use, but the towel allotment was pretty stingy (one washcloth, hand towel, and bath towel per person) so the extra towels came in handy.  2. As others have noted, there are no paper plates, cups, or utensils. There was a full roll of paper towels. Plus, not

Spent 2 nights in Cottage #14 with good longtime friends.  We know the area and live close so stayed put for our 3 day visit except for long beach walks, sitting on the beach, toasting marshmallows on the beach (and eating out). I guess you notice the beach theme here. You might want to online research a bit about the history of Crystal Cove Cottages to enhance your experience before your stay. There is even info about who built this particular cottage and the tale of many movies made in the cove area. If you don’t do that reading ahead there is a coffee table unit in the house which you should give yourself some time to glance at.   1. A locally owned cat has figured how how to jump through any open windows (no screens ) and join you in the living area. If that bugs you then I

Summary Heading: Rustic beachfront cottage to unplug and relax
Summary: A friend alerted me to a 3-day cancellation she saw on the reservecalifornia.com website less than a week away starting on Halloween night.  I logged in and booked cottage 19B, a downstairs studio right on the beach.  Reservations and cancellations are difficult to get, so if you see one that’s not set aside for handicapped guests, take it.  Be aware that if you cancel in less than a week, you’ll need to pay for the first night.     I searched for information on the cottage and found someone had done a YouTube video so we knew what to expect.  19B is a small, ground floor studio, beach front unit with a full-size bed, and only a microwave and small refrigerator.  There is no phone, no usable wifi, no hairdryer, no toiletries, or TV, which suited us fine.  Due to the pandemic,
Room tip: Some cottages are bluff top, some are beachfront, some are handicapped.  Mid-week is easiest to...

Summary Heading: Really lucky, had a cancellation and grabbed it!
Summary: Someone had a reservation for 3 nights and did not bother to call, email, or text. Just happened to be in the right place at the right time and at noon the unit was ours.  Possibly for a second night as well. If you have ever wanted to live in the 1940’s this is the paled for you. These have been renovated to safety standards but most of the furnishings are vintage. Originally began as found materials by Ranch hands of a long ago Irvine Ranch that covered a major portion of Orange County, these were updated over time to become weekend homes by generations of the same family.  Located directly on the beach these are a tremendous value now for a room.

Our stay was fun and memorable for our family. We brought more food from home and ate casual meals in our cottage. It was helpful for us to bring a few more blankets for cozy time and our own coffee pot. The staff was very helpful moving gear from our car to the golf carts to take you to the cottages. You then move your car to across the street. You can walk to your car through an under highway passage, about a 10-15min walk.  Going to sleep with the sounds of the waves was awesome. The cottages are rustic but very clean.  19A was a great cottage with 2 private bedrooms with the main table and couch in the middle. The 1 bathroom is connected to the master bedroom. There is one covered patio facing the beach and another larger deck to the side, not with as beautiful views.  It is

I love Crystal Cove cottages and will keep coming back.  It is still one of my favorite places.  Stayed in a dorm, where you share facilities, but this was the first time I shared my bed with a mouse   =(. I'll be bringing a plug in repellent next time.  It would be helpful if folks  would keep exterior doors closed as instructed and kept all food put away!

I’m writing this as I sit at the dining table of the cottage, looking out the window as the waves curl onto the beach. All weekend long, my family and I have enjoyed this amazing view.   Let’s face it, you stay at the cottages for the views and access to the beach. The accommodations are rustic with entirely vintage (used) furnishings. I loved the vintage kitchen and decor of the cottage. However, the mattresses and sofa weren’t vintage, they were cheap. They were not comfortable, and I could hear the springs every time I moved on them. Basically, they are furniture from a cheap motel. I don’t think upgrading the beds would lessen the experience.   Some things to know before you book: -They have you unload your belongings at the entrance of the resort and shuttle you and your

Summary Heading: Affordable spot to vacation right on the beach, difficult to reserve
Summary: Every time I land a booking, I feel like the luckiest person ever. I have only been able to reserve through last minute cancellations as the online booking months ahead sells out in seconds. I've stayed in many cottages and dorm rooms and love them all. Each has its own charm. They are rustic but comfortable. They provide sheets and towels and you make your own beds. Instead of dining at a restaurant in Newport or Laguna, get take out or go to Trader Joes, and dine on your deck on the sand or high on the bluffs. Cottages have fridges and microwaves, sinks and bathrooms with showers. Some ADA units have stoves, at least they did a few years ago when I stayed in a dorm room that had an ADA approved kitchen as part of the entire cottage. I've brought my own electric skillet and
Room tip: Cottages are sometimes available to walkins

Summary: We were so excited to finally get a reservation here as we had been trying for years.  We stayed in 39B, a dorm style room.   It had amazing views and we could watch dolphins from our window.  It does share a bathroom with another room which was the only reason it was not excellent.

Oh, to actually own one of these quaint beach cottages. Pushing that aside, renting a cottage is wonderful. They are spartan—no heat in the winter (which can get cold) or air-conditioning in the summer. Still, these are cottages, lovingly restored from the 1930s (when they were originally built) to when they were vacated in the 1990s. The Irvine Company owned the land and allowed tenants to erect their slap-dab shanties. But when Irvine decided to sell The Cove to possible hotel developers, former cottage owners created a conservancy along with the state to create Crystal Cove State Park. Cottages were saved and are now available for nightly stays. Some are dorms (with shared bathrooms and kitchen) while others are free-standing with their own amenities. I, of course, prefer the

Summary Heading: stayed in 39b sleeps four hear the ocen all night
Summary: This was a dorm room with shared bathroom. It had two sets of bunk beds. I saw dolphins also beautiful sunsets. There is also microwave and refrigerator. Very nice beach to walk and sun on. You hear the waves crashing all night long very serene no tv.

We scored an ever elusive reservation at the cove! We were able to get two rooms in dorm style Cottage 39. This cottage is adorable, with a small living room, kitchen and a gorgeous ocean view deck. 39B has four bunk beds nestled tightly into a small room and it has a large window that faces the coast. It shares a Jack and Jill bathroom with 39A. 39B is a large room with a full and two single beds. The magic of this room is the giant windows wrapping around the side and front of the room.  You can lay in any of the beds and see the beautiful ocean while listening to the waves crashing. The kitchen has a fridge, toaster and microwave and you can bring a small grill and bbq. This place is amazing!

I've been fortunate enough to stay in several dorm rooms over the last several years.  39C is the only one with A Private Bathroom (!).  This tiny room has no ocean view.  There is a window that faces the walkway, to bring in air and light, and tiny windows in the bathroom (sink, toilet, shower).  The door opens practically right into the kitchen, but that was not an issue.  The dorm itself has a dining/sitting room and a simply wonderful deck.  This room is great for one person or two people who like each other.  There is a closet (why is there a lock/chain on the outside of that door?  What might be coming through there?) that is big enough to stow suitcases, beach chairs, etc.  There are shelves in the bathroom for storing the provided towels and some incidentals.  There is

These cottages are seriously the cutest. We got lucky and got to stay at one of the cottages after a cancellation, which rarely happens. We were told you usually have to rent these out 6 months in advance due to popularity.  It was $71 total for 4 of us to stay for a night, and it has a perfect view of the Pacific ocean. It was literally all of our favorite spots on our trip to California.

Lovely setting near the sea.  Wonderful place to stay!  Going to sleep with the Ocean's roar.  Time spent reading on the beach or in the sunny porch.  No tvs!  time for conversation and board games and relaxation!

We booked months in advance because it is so difficult to find a vacancy and snagged one night.  We were so looking forward to a relaxing time by the beach.  Check in was smooth.   But then right below our window, a wedding reception with band and speakers facing us was setting up.    And the wedding itself was taking place a few cottages down.   On top of that the Beachcomber was closed that day for renovations.   No one had told us.  We only brought a few snacks with us.   And The Shack Shed up a steep flight of steps had long lines.  The conservancy has no control over the privately owned cottages   We packed up and left as the music ramped up and destroyed all possibility of any sort of relaxing evening.    We will not be going back again.   Canceled our January reservation.

I was lucky to re t cabin 27 during the summer and it was the most amazing and relaxing 4 days vacation. Cabin is cozy and i loved hearing the waves crashing in the sand. Hard to rent this gems but so worth it.

Summary Heading: A great place to stay.  The beach is great and the restaurant on the sand is fabulous.  It's called the Beachcomber.
Summary: I have stayed at three different cottages over the years.  Almost all of them have great ocean views.  A very fun place to stay.  They have beach BBQ's that you can rent also.  Book it at reservecalifornia.com

My 4 close friends and I had a lovely 4 day visit to celebrate our 50th birthdays.  We loved every minute!  The fall sunsets can’t be beat.  There are 4 tall chairs overlooking the beach and Beachcomber restaurant.  There are also 4 chairs around a back patio table.  We brought an extra folding chair to accommodate our whole group.  We also brought a plug in skillet for eggs and pancakes and a coffee press.  The kitchen has a toaster and although small, it has a lot of storage space for extra stuff like coffee mugs and blenders😉. The 2 Murphy beds are comfortable and fold down into the main living space where there is a farm style long table and bench.  The bathroom is small and we used the closet in the hallwayoutside to set up a tray to hold our toiletries.  This is a great

IF I HAVE THE OPTION I'D PUT NO STARS AT ALL, OR MAYBE MINUS FIVE STARS. I have been trying to book a cabin for a few years, but it has been almost impossible.  It is usually fully booked six month in advance.  On October 4, 2018, I gave it another try and luckily I found an opening for one day, October 7, 2018.  I booked it right away before it disappears again thru reservecalifornia.com website. After I finished the online transaction, and refreshed the webpage, I found out that October 6 had also opened up for reservation. I thought it was my lucky day, somebody must have cancelled just two days before their arrival day.  I booked that day as well in a separate transaction for a total of $519.98 ($259.99 per night).  Unfortunately, my elderly mom got suddenly very sick on

We stayed in cottage #29 during a particularly hot few days. Very little bad to say about this place. The cottages are beautiful and historic - no frills, unrefined and unique.   The beach is just about perfect, with food to buy and chairs/umbrellas to rent. Waves were great for bodyboarding but not too crazy for young kids. If you stay on the cliff as we did, expect to walk a million stairs to get to the beach. Also, you have to park across the freeway and walk into the park - about a 10-minute hike. Very doable, but sweat-inducing on a hot day.  Food is expensive but good, including the Shake Shack. Lines can be long, both at the restaurant and the Shake Shack.  The only bad part is that our room had only one small window that could be opened. With temps around 90 and no AC,

this is not a 5-star accommodation, but I just love hearing the ocean from the dorms with ocean views. dorms have a small kitchen and patio overlooking the beach and ocean. the shared bath can be bothersome. Or pay $160 + for your own small cottage. family friendly beach. pricey restaurant on the beach. walk up to sugar shack for shakes or more. trader joes close by down PCH. recommended if you want to experience the "old times". meutermedia

The cottages are lovely and most have spectacular views. Some cottages have shared facilities which were cleaned daily by staff. The beach is beautiful and hopefully someday they will be able to complete the renovations on all of the other buildings on the property.  Good points: Free coffee/tea all day, free wi-fi, restaurants on site, free parking, miles of spectacular beach, sunsets to remember for a life time and an abundance of wild life to watch.  Bad Points. Some of the rooms have a Bed Bug problems that they are trying to deal with.

A secret hideaway in Crystal Cove! Very small and private away from the hustle and bustle of everyday life! The entrees at the Beachcomer are exceptional and you won’t be disappointed! The halibut was cooked to perfection and the chicken entree was superb!!! A must if you have an occasion for a special celebration or if your looking for a secret little hideaway!

Summary Heading: A little piece of gold from the Gold Coast
Summary: We stayed in a basement studio that was on the sand in 12 feet. The location was spectacular with sunsets at you front door. The snorkeling was fantastic with lobsters in the ellgrass and a plethora of sea life in hands reach. The room was just a place to lay your head with the sound of the surf pounding pounding outside of your door. The Restaurant was just a few steps away on the other side of the creek. What a great place to nourish your body and soul. The food is fantastic and the ambience brings you back to the golden beach days that very few could enjoy. Now anyone can rent these golden gems, Beach house of the rich and famous.

We were lucky to find an opening at Crystal Cove Beach Cottages. Very quaint lodging, with the wonderful sound of the waves on the beach lulled me to sleep. The Beachcomber Café is on site and is a local gem for any meal. The sunset and the views from our cottage are the best if you happen to love the ocean.

Summary Heading: Another magical experience at Crystal Cove
Summary: This was our fourth visit, and our third stay in the cozy Shell Shack.  We got some variable weather this time, including rain, and the changing sky made for some unique lighting for our photos.  The sunsets were spectacular and inspiring as always, and overnight we were both soothed and excited by the sound of the surf right outside our door.  By now, we know just what to bring to Crystal Cove, including our portable coffee maker.  All of it rides from the visitor's center where our van is temporarily parked, down to our cottage and back.  Parking is across the highway, so we walk or take the shuttle bus to get back and forth.  The Beachcomber Restaurant is right next door to the Shell Shack, handy for our meals, and the 30s music they play fits right in with the nostalgic mood

Had an awesome one night stay in dorm style cottage room 38A. The room has a single bed and single bunk beds. It also has an old small wooden table with two chairs and a wall with large windows overlooking the patio and ocean. There is another patio on the other side of the kitchen for the three rooms on that side. This room shares bathrooms with the rest of the house but there are two full baths and one half bath so there were no issues, even though the house was full. There is a small shared living room with a couple of chairs and a large shared kitchen with two picnic tables, two refrigerators, a microwave and a toaster. We had a great afternoon on the patio; went to Beachcomber for a delicious dinner and spent this morning with an early morning nibble, a carafe of coffee

I've had the fun of staying in several of the dorm rooms in cottage 38 on the bluff, and this was the first time I've been in 38B.    This room does not have an ocean view and the window opens to the walk-way.  PCH is nearby, so there are traffic sounds occasionally.  The room backs up to one of the bathrooms, so there are flushing and shower sounds through the rather thin walls.  There is a full-size bed (which is easy to make) and a bunkbed.  If you will be using the bunkbeds (in this room or any of the dorm rooms), I highly recommend bringing sleeping bags just to keep things easy.  There is plenty of seating in the shared dining area.  There are two refrigerators, a toaster, microwave and hot plate.  The two decks provide gorgeous views.    I really liked having the two

Summary Heading: Here is some information most reviewers don't include...
Summary: We had Cottage #27 the Dive Shack.  Most reviewers tell you what a great time they had and how cute the cottage is... all of which is true, and I agree with, so I won't repeat it because you've heard it all before.  Here is some information most reviewers don't include that I hope will be more helpful to you:  There are plenty of electrical outlets in all the rooms.  Even though there is not a stove you could easily bring a crock pot, a George Foreman grill or an electric griddle, etc.  We brought a coffee pot and were glad of it. The kitchen does have a toaster, a microwave and a decent sized fridge with a freezer that works.  We also brought an electrical strip that came in handy.  Also, in the kitchen they provide PAPER plates and napkins and PLASTIC utensils and cups.  And

I was pleasantly surprised with a nice, secluded getaway.  The logistics for parking was awkward, located across the street and up the hill. We took their shuttle to the cottage which required 1,50 per person.  When told the driver our cottage number, he had no idea where to take us. He insisted we tell him if they were the upper or lower ones. We took a guess and said lower. Good thing we were right, because it would’ve been quite a hike with our luggage. The cottage we rented was #2, but we arrived late at night and the number was hidden behind a candy cane.  So we walked up to the host of the restaurant that was right next to our cottage and asked him if he knew where cottage number 2 was. He looked annoyed and pointed us on the direction of a map. I later informed hi for his

Summary Heading: Truly one of a kind experience... step back in time!
Summary: We were lucky enough to score a cottage that was a last minute cancellation from another party as you have to book them 6 mths in advance as they are very very popular.  Enjoyed our ocean front view from the bluff. The cottage we had was built around 1920 and was updated somewhat but still retained it's nostalgic charm.  This is definitely an experience so don't expect shampoo/conditioner/lotion and comfy robes.  You are staying here to experience old California beach bungalow life and it really is incredible.  Also, that beach (Crystal Cove) runs over 3 miles long and has really firm sand so you can walk for a great distance and guess what....it's just beach and scenery and not cluttered with houses, businesses, and crowds.  It's so special.  There are 2 places to get food

Summary Heading: Beach fun in Nastalgic cottages of Christal Cove State Park
Summary: We stayed in 29A , a dorm style experience that was very pleasant. You share the living room ,kitchen and a deck overlooking the beach on the cliff. The sound of the surf lulls you to sleep any time of the day or night. The bedroom has a double bed and 4 bunk beds. The double bed needed a little support in the middle but I slept well. You have a place on the deck for your gas BBQ and plenty of tables and chairs to enjoy. The kitchen has a retro refrigerator and a modern microwave. The stove and room heater are historical and do not work. The fireplace has been bricked in so it is historic too. The Restaurant is the best and a little pricey but worth it. There are many historic museum cottages with old time feelings. Your family will totally enjoy your stay.

Ever time we have visited SC we have always been curious about this place so we took the plunge and did a day trip . We stopped and ate at the beach combers restaurant which the food was amazing but for lunch very high end . We probably would not do it again - the resort itself is like a vintage back in the 50-60 era ... ummm that was then this is now but what’s crazy is the beach houses are booked out all year around and well I guess it’s not for us .

Summary Heading: #33 Romantic Retreat - great views, nice deck, crappy cottage :~/
Summary: I am a local and have stayed at five different cottages throughout the years. I understand the cottages are "rustic" but this one was a little much! #33 was my least favorite. Tiny place with a miniature bathroom, kind of dirty - from dead bugs in the light fixtures, spider webs around the outside of the doors (couldn't the cleaning crew knock them down??), even the sofa bed looked dirty - didn't want to sit on it. its like they really need to schedule monthly pest control and at least a monthly deep cleaning. Yes, the view was incredible - being up on the bluff really gave you a great view. Sunset was to die for! But then we had to go back inside :~/

This room sits on the bluff and is a shared cottage with one other bedroom that might give you up to 6 additional housemates. Quiet time is from 10pm-8am, and we were thankful to have considerate roomies.  29B is a loft above the kitchen with 4 twin beds (watch your head!!) and a table, great for games, crafts, snacks.  The bathroom is downstairs, but not shared with 29A.  Guests share the kitchen, dining area, living room and deck.  Fridge and microwave, paper plates and utensils are provided. Its nice that the loft is not above the other bedroom (29A). Still, this IS a loft, not a closed off room, so voices and sounds carry.  Beautiful views from the deck, long walk down to the beach.

Summary Heading: Stumbled upon a magical beach movie...
Summary: My husband and I had a few free hours to get to a beach and walk, so driving down Highway 1, we hopped off at Crystal Cove State Park. We just walked along and absorbed the gorgeous views when we stumbled upon a cluster of ramshackle beach cottages (right on the beach) and wondered if we were in a Twilight Zone episode. Started reading plaques and information, stopped at the wonderfully casual beach bar for a beer and found out more about this treasure. These cottages book a year ahead of time. Now, every time I'm in California, I'm going to check to see if there is a rare cancellation at Crystal Cove that I can nab.

Summary Heading: Total relaxation with the ocean at at the Shell Shack
Summary: This was our fourth visit to Crystal Cove, and we were lucky enough to be able to stay in our beloved Shell Shack once again. The best feature of the Shell Shack, which has the layout of a studio apartment, is the covered front porch.  From here we spend hours gazing out over the ocean and experiencing the rhythms of the shifting tide, the movements of the sun, and the comings and goings of visitors enjoying the beach.  For anyone who has to avoid the searing sun on their skin (like me), this covered porch is invaluable.  But wherever you are at Crystal Cove, the vastness of the ocean takes over.  The sound of the crashing surf is steady and unending, and a joy to go to sleep by and wake up to.  The day begins with the beach nearly deserted as light gradually drifts over the

Summary Heading: Crystal Cove Beach Cottages - Cottage 19A - South Sea Shanty
Summary: We stayed in Cottage 19A March 20-23, 2017.  Needless to say the cottage is very quaint with all the basic necessities that one needs while staying on the beach.    The weather was not perfect, but we didn't even care; just thankful to be at such a beautiful environment.    Couple hints that I came across:  (1) next to impossible to get a reservation on the first of the month, attempting to get lucky throughout the day hoping for a cancellation I believe is a more reasonable expectation of getting a reservation.  Have to be able to be flexible on the dates as well; (2) pack as little as possible, the distance from the cottages to the car is very far and trying to drag your luggage via the sand, doesn't work very well, especially wheelies.  They have a little golf cart for this

It takes luck to get a reservation for one of the Crystal Cove Beach Cottages.  We were in Cottage 32 which is a few steps from the beach, has fantastic views, and is close to the restaurant.  The cottage has been carefully restored to what it must have been like in the 1920s.  Consistent with that it has very steep stairs, only a small bathroom through which you walk to get to the back patio, and a very small living room for a place that can sleep 9 people.  It also has a very small front porch.  We were there on cold nights where the space heater in the living room was insufficient to keep the bedrooms warm.  This is an amazing and unique place and well worth the effort and time on the website to try to land a reservation.

Summary Heading: exciting stormy stay on the beach
Summary: We were lucky enough to walk in and get a room in one of the cottages right on the beach during an epic wind and rain storm. By the time we got down the many stairs to the "quarters" we were soaked. Then the car had to be moved to the parking lot. OK! A memorable experience and an excellent heater, trip snacks and popcorn dinner and roaring wind and waves. Great stay and helpful staff. Not a luxury stay but memorable!

The location is amazing! On the pristine shore of Crystal Cove State Park. The cottages are charming and beautiful, though the beds and appliances haven't been updated in decades. Despite that, if you can get a reservation, it's a must!

Joined our family who live here for a sunset bonfire on the beach.  We made reservations and they set everything up wonderfully. Chairs, fire pits and server included.   They provided all ingredients for smores and brought beverages upon arrival.    What an amazing night with a great sunset and family.  Highly recommend you check this out !

Summary Heading: Great Night in Paradise Lodge, Cabin #39
Summary: We Love Crystal Cove and the Historic Beach Cottages This was our third overnight stay and one of Many visits to the beach. Paradise Lodge is actually on the bluff, overlooking the beach. It is a dorm style cabin with 3 bedrooms. We stayed in "C" which does not have an ocean view, but does have it's own bathroom. Just had to open the door and look through the kitchen window to see the ocean. There is a shared kitchen, sitting area, and Great outdoor patio. Looking forward to our next visit.

We stayed at the cute little yellow cottage #40 November 11-13 2016. The weather was great and the views from the beach front porch were amazing.  It is a tiny studio cottage with a twin bed and a full bed. The bathroom is huge and the little kitchen provides all you need. It has a toaster, microwave, and small fridge. There is a Trader Joe's just down the street where you can pick up yummy microwave meals, and perfect snacks.  We got bagels, cream cheese, capers, and lox for breakfast and felt like stars eating on the patio every morning. Awesome get away!

I have spent the last 25 years in Southern California. I used to do a triathlon at Crystal Cove many years back. A few years ago Crystal Cove became a state park. It was the best thing that the state of California has ever done in my humble opinion. We normally camp at Crystal Cove but we were lucky enough to get one night at Cottage number 37 the fisherman Cottage. A couple of my girlfriends and I came down to do a quick catch-up and hang at the beach. The Cottages have been redone but maintain their 1920 humble appearance and interior. The larger Cottages are $245 and night. Although there are not cooking facilities we saw that you could bring a propane grill to barbecue. They provide paper plates and cups. Towels and sheets are included. The cottages are extremely clean.  If

Have not yet stayed at Crystal Cove, learned of the properties until August of 2016, able to reserve cottage 19A in March of 2017 for 3 nights.  My experience is to reserve these quaint one of a kind cottages, is to be diligent.  I was able to secure a 3 night stay on September 13, 2016.  So, in my opinion, ALL the bad reviews for not being able to reserve these cottages, is just for lack of trying!  Cannot wait to go......

My friends and I spent the day at Crystal Cove beach. What a glorious day. The water was cool.....and very refreshing after baking in the sun. A great day for boogie boarding and swimming in the ocean. There is a bar and restaurant near the sand. There is a Ruby's diner up the steps. Lots of memorabilia...like the cottage from the movie Beaches and old summer cottages from the past. There is a gift shop....with reasonable prices and a little museum. Parking is $15.00 for the day and there is a shuttle from the parking to the beach. You can drop off people and beach supplies then drive to the parking area....a great convenience.

Summary Heading: Romantic hideaway with waves and stars in studio 19B
Summary: I love coming to Crystal Cove for getaways with my husband. Sometimes we even let the family come along! This was the first time we had stayed in summer and it was surprising to see such a crowded beach. So many colorful umbrellas and families equipped to stay all day and take advantage of this beautiful place. In summer the tide is much higher and it appears to be a narrower beach.But, there was plenty of room for all who were there and it really seemed like a great family outing. Staff drove us to our room, 19B. This is a studio that is under 19A and is literally right on the beach. Literally only about 5 paces from the sand. The waves were bigger than I had seen them before and body surfers were having a ball. When we opened the door I was in love with this little find. I

Great location right on the beach.  You can watch your kids from the balcony.  Six of us stayed.  Only inconvenience was it had only one bathroom. Bring a camping stove to minor cooking.  The prices at the Ruby's Shake Shack and the Beachcomber were very reasonable and the food was great.  Get the special Bloody Mary at the Beachcomber.

Summary Heading: As unique an experience as it gets...
Summary: Stayed in cottage 40 which is small unit with two beds (single and double).  Location probably the closest to the ocean and close to Beachcombers (restaurant/bar about 100 feet away).  The restaurant noise didn't disturb us despite this being one of the most busy stretches of beach.  For those of us who don't own beachfront homes, this is a great alternative if you don't mind a lot of foot traffic in front of your cottage.  The deck on this cottage is extra large and you'll spend hours people watching.  These cottages are rustic (the bed frame is old and too short for me 6'2" but I managed) but totally functional.  There's a little bit of history in this unit and since it is ADA approved had a large bathroom.  Expect a July 4th vibe during the summer, with miles of coastline,

Summary Heading: Another fantastic stay at Crystal Cove
Summary: We were lucky enough to book our second stay at the Shell Shack with a view overlooking the beach.  Days pass calmly here from sunrise to sunset, with the sound of the pounding surf always keeping time.  The Shell Shack offers the catbird seat, with the peaceful view of daybreak over the ocean and later lots of people-watching as crowds come in to enjoy the beach.  Each day ends with awe-inspiring sunset views from the balcony.  The Beachcomber restaurant is right downstairs for beachside meals if you like, or you can take the hike up the hillside stairway to Ruby's Shake Shack.  The Shell Shack cottage is one large room that's perfect for a couple, though it also has beds to accommodate several people.  We'd be happy to stay in any cottage at Crystal Cove, although this is our

I have enjoyed many stays in various dorm rooms at the Cottages, but this was my first individual cottage getaway.  Two differences I noted immediately:  more privacy (of course) and more storage space.    Cottage 14 is on the beach, just south of the historic district and the tide pools are nearly directly in front.  The cottage is approached by a narrow flight of stairs that bring you to a generously sized deck with picnic table, umbrella and additional seating.  Another short flight of steps brings you to the front door.  The main floor has an open kitchen area with microwave, toaster and really cute vintage fridge, plus lots of space for storing whatever food you bring. There is a dining table for 6, comfy sitting area which includes a queen size sofa bed that we did not

If you want to step back in time relax by the sound of the waves.  This is the place to be.  Very hard  to get a cottage you have to book six months in advance,  if you're lucky enough to get one.  You have to get on line the first of each month to book.  They go fast so good luck. We took the sea glass class they have it every Wed.  Rick the man in charge of the sea glass class is a joy to chat with and learn about Crystal Cove.

I can't say enough good things about Crystal Cove! Before you decide to stay, please remember this is not a hotel with room service; being prepared is important! Here are some things we have learned:  Even though the check in is rather late, you can always come early for lunch at the Shake Shack or a walk on the beach before your room is ready. Wear comfortable shoes so you can enjoy the walk from the parking lot.   There are only microwaves in most cabins (ADA cabins have a cook top) and paper plates and plastic forks, spoons and knives. Bring your own if you want something other than that. We bring our camping gear with real mugs for coffee. Sometimes we bring a crock-pot or electric grill if we are staying for a few days. You are renting a wonderful, historic cottage with a

First, many reviews here state that reservations are taken 6 months in advance, which is incorrect.  From their website:  "Reservations must be made 2 Day(s) ahead of arrival and can be made up to 7 Month(s) in advance."  For example, the next time-block will open for reservations on December 1st at 8am PST.  The reservations will be for the month of June. Personally, I've never had any success with the 8am booking.  I have always found a reservation via cancellation and planned my trip once a reservation was secured.  OK, with that out of the way . . . this is my favorite place to stay when I'm in Orange County.  Just steps away from the beach, this is "glamping" at its finest.  The only caveat is to realize, this is not a hotel or a luxury destination.  It is extremely rustic.

Crystal Cove Beach Cottages are an amazing way to experience the beach, ocean and So Cal coast.  Several cottages are steps from the beach.  The cottages have been renovated over the last several years.  During the early morning (before 8 a.m.) and in the evenings after 6 p.m., you feel like you are on your own private beach.

Great beach for families. Historic beach bungalows restored from the 20's, 30's, and 40's. Beachcomber restaurant is located there also with great bar drinks and food. Need to reserve a cottage way in advance! Day tripping is one of the best ways o get a feel for the place as well as get information about the state park and rentals.

Summary Heading: Step back in time and enjoy the view and the sound of the ocean
Summary: I was lucky enough to get a one-night stay at the Painter’s Cottage (#32) at the Crystal Cove State Beach Cottages.  I had originally planned on there being other people coming with me and my son, but they canceled as it was a mid-week reservation during the school year.  And part of me wanted to cancel as well when I saw the forecast for rain during our stay.  However, I had been intrigued by the whole idea of this little enclave of cottages that harken back to the 1930s and a different time - so my son and I went.  SO GLAD we did!  Wow, was it an experience!  We were lucky enough that it wasn't crowded (probably due to the dire forecasts of rain and thunderstorms) and we got there about 5 pm with sunset around 8 pm.  Our cottage was quaint (and quite big for only the two of

We stayed in dorm 29A for a wonderful September weekend.  It has a bathroom with shower, 1 double bed and 4 twin bunk beds.  There is a very nice patio with a round table and BQ area.   29B is a loft sleeping with a large living area. It also has a patio.  There is a large refrigrat and microwave.  The location is on the bluffs.

We snagged a one-night cancellation for 38D - one of our party has mobility issues and needs ADA accomodation. Lovely bluff top cottage - 5 private separate bedrooms, with 4 baths, a common kitchen and living room and long deck with unsurpassed views. Although very basic, everything was extremely clean. We were there on a hot day - room took a  little while to cool off. No a/c, but ceiling fan and box fan worked pretty well. Had dinner at the Beachcomber Cafe - excellent food, not just a novelty location. Bed was comfortable - slept well with the beautiful sound of waves. I woke up in the night because a light was shining in - it was the moon! So we walked out and enjoyed the moonlight on the deck - unforgettable -   It is not easy to get a reservation - at 8 am on the first of

Summary Heading: You just can't beat the view!
Summary: The cottages are a step back in time to the late 30's.  A simpler way of life without distractions.  No tv or Wi-fi - just the beauty of nature and the crashing of waves on shore.  Time to reflect and watch a family of dolphins swim by or see the sailboats off in the distance.  It is rustic and charming and always a great break from the normal routine.  Just sit back, relax and enjoy!

Summary Heading: What you need to know if you want to stay at Crystal Cove Cottages
Summary: Enjoying a trip is often about managing expectations and having a “local’s perspective” about the location.  Crystal Cove (and the cottages) has seen a fascinating history that has not been without controversy.  Tug-of-wars over land, ownership and occupancy rights has led to the current situation today, where four different organizations claim usage rights to this small cove on the Pacific Coast in Orange County.  Understanding this fact will help you better plan and enjoy your stay.  Note that for this review I will use the term “Crystal Cove” for the small cove with the cottages and the restaurant, and “Crystal Cove State Park” for the much larger stretch of land that extends 3 miles to the north and includes the cove at its south end.  When Crystal Cove first started being

Summary Heading: Cottage #1 - The Beach Pad, Crystal Cove
Summary: Enjoyed a week in cottage #1 at Crystal Cove.  "The Beach Pad" is ADA accessible and sleeps 4 persons (maximum of 6 allowed).  It is right on the beach and has a long partially covered porch with multiple chairs, picnic benches and patio umbrellas to enjoy the spectacular view.  The Beachcomber restaurant is only a few cottages away.  The interior is somewhat rustic and includes a large living room, dining room, kitchen with 2 refrigerators/microwave/burner, 2 bedrooms, and full bath.  The sound of the crashing surf can be heard from all rooms in the cottage, a perfect sleeping aid.  Parking is fairly close as long as you have a handicap placard.  Overall, a very relaxing and memorable vacation on a gem of a beach in So Cal.

Summary Heading: Another wondeful visit to magical Crystal Cove
Summary: Almost miraculously, an opening popped up one sleepy Sunday afternoon on the usually unforgiving Crystal Cove Beach Cottages online board.  And so we were lucky enough to make a second visit to this vintage oceanside resort.  This time we stayed in the Soda Shack, cottage 45, which in earlier times was a classic soda fountain serving the beachgoers.  It has been lovingly refurbished into a cozy and comfortable retreat.  The Soda Shack is a quick walk from the beach and next store to the gift shop - not the ideal location.  There is a bit of noise early morning with park maintenance machinery passing by, and with people walking to and from the trail to the parking lot across the highway.  However, the Soda Shack was just fine for the shorter days of our late April visit, since we

We stayed in Cottage # 2- The Shell Shack. Its located right next to the Beachcomber Restaurant. Its the upper park of the structure only (restaurant staff uses below) and basically 1 huge room with 2 full size Murphy beds, a day bed and a pull out sofa sleeper. The Murphy bed was very comfortable but we were glad we brought blankets as it was chilly at night. Floors are concrete so bring socks/slippers too. lol... The room was insulated from outside noise (for the most part) aside from when the restaurants refrigeration unit would run at night. The staff was up early getting ready for the crowds as well. But it wasn't bad. Summer would be much louder. The food and service at The Beachcomber restaurant and bar side was great! The Shake Shack is up on the hill as well with yummy

Summary Heading: 2 more wonderful stays at The Cove
Summary: Since my last review we have enjoyed the cove cottages a total of four nights during 2 different stays. We have lucked out and had beautiful "winter" weather. The migrant birds we saw last week were amazing I had never seen so species at the beach. I am no bird watcher but the royal terns, oystercatchers, sanderlings,black turnstones, plovers, brown pelicans and many different gulls made for some beautiful views and photos. Last week we were in 39c dorm room with private bath, the other 2 rooms in this cottage 39a and b share a bath which you can be locked out of if the sharing room  forgets to unlock the door. Also at full capacity 8 people could be sharing the one small bath. Cottage 38 has a much better set up with the shared baths....no locking doors. Our experience has only

I'm not one for "relaxing" vacations, usually I need lots of things to distract me. But, here is different. A couple of nights in a vintage beach cottage with the waves crashing is just the ticket. Slow down and enjoy taking walks on the beach, tidepooling, and watching the wildlife. Trader Joe's is less than a mile away, and has everything you need to eat happily. And if you need to be connected, the free wifi meets your needs perfectly. Two different restaurants and a beach bar add to the fun.

We loved the two nights we spent at Crystal Cove Beach Cottages. We loved being able to relax in the living room with a glass of wine and watch the sun set over the cove. We loved being able to linger over breakfast on the deck as the fog lifted and to take a leisurely walk on the beach, wading through the crystal waters and checking out the little creatures in the tide pools. We loved that it was kind of "laid back bohemian" rather than a fancy resort. Our visit was in winter and we would have enjoyed more stormy weather if it had been raining, but as it turned out, the sun was warm and welcoming during the day. Nights were pretty nippy, though, and the cottages aren't as well insulated as traditional homes and hotels, so we were glad for the blankets on the bed and would

I was lucky enough to snag a reservation for a short January stay. One thing to be aware of is that there is a huge amount of variability between the different cottages since each has a unique configuration. Mine (38B) had four bunk beds and a shared bath. Since there were only two of us we were able to cuddle up in one of the twin sized beds, but it wasn't the most comfortable sleep. But the breathtaking full ocean view and the beautiful surroundings made up for the bed(s). If I return, I'll pay more attention to the bathroom situation since we were sharing with a room that had a fairly large family - this sometimes led to long waits. Again, all in all for the price and the great location this place is a fantastic value. Just be aware that more than likely you'll have to share

Every cottages is unique. Make sure you review the crystal cover cottages website when making reservations so you know what you are getting.  We stayed in the dorm-style Paradise Lodge. Dorm-style means one cottage with three separate rooms that can be reserved.  We stayed in the very small 39B with twin bunk beds. We could see the ocean from our window, but only stayed in the room to sleep and change. The rest of the time when we were at the lodge, we were in the Hawaiian-themed living room or on the expansive deck. 39A is the room to be in in this lodge. It was more spacious and had two extremely large windows to view the ocean. 39C has its own private bathroom (yes 39A and 39B share a restroom which could make things interesting), but has no view of the beach. However, the

Summary Heading: Some thoughts about our stay at Crystal Cove –
Summary: During check in it was suggested that we park near the garages to unload and load our belongings to / from Cottage 45, Soda Shack, which is near the turnaround; instead of using the cart service.    The Beachcomber bus shuttles between the rear of Los Trancos parking lot and the turnaround; $1 with good period music. The Cottage rental parking arrangement is separate from the State Park system. You need $15 to use the other Crystal Cove State Park lots for hiking, picnicking, sightseeing, and Visitor Center during one day; or a State pass of some type.  Cottage 45 was the second of three soda / store structures located at the end of the main road, all where Cottage 46 is now situated. Cottage 45 was built about 1935 and lasted until about 1950 when it had a run in with the

In the last 2 months we have re-booked  2 cancellations, one for 1 evening and one for 2.Both times we stayed in the dorm cottages. Is all I can say is the view from the bluff is awesome. Staff is helpful and friendly. Others have done excellent descriptions on what  dorms are like so no need for me to repeat. Do understand the rooms are very small and the accommodations very basic.

We stayed in 38b on a cancellation that we got 2 weeks before. It's a dorm style room. Imagine a big house and everyone gets a bedroom with a lock on the door. The bathroom, deck and kitchen are all common areas. Linens and a tiny bar of soap are provided. Prepare to put your sheets on your bed. It was a nice staycation. We spent the day at the beach with friends and had lunch at the Shake Shack. Then we met up with more friends and had dinner at the Beachcomber. Parking is across PCH so don't lug too much stuff. There isn't parking too close for loading but there is a temporary loading area still not too close if you have a lot of stuff.

We were very, very lucky and managed to get a cancellation.   We stayed one night in the dorm style cottages way back in 2010. We bought our food and drink from the local supermarket and got to know the rest of the people staying in our dorm. We visited again in 2012 but couldn't get a room so we spent the whole day on the beach and went to the restaurant instead, which was also really nice.  An amazing ocean view (we saw dolphins swimming across the cove), great price and nice rooms and a really fantastic restaurant with really friendly staff too. When I die this is what I hope heaven is like! : )

My mom and I stayed here for a one night stay-cation and had a wonderful time. From what I've gathered by looking at other pictures, I think that we were blessed with one of the more light and airy cottages. It was actually really cute and when I do come back in the future, I will be on the look out for cottage #39.   Our cottage had 2 bunk beds, which weren't the most comfortable things on earth & the linens are a bit rough so it's hard to get comfortable. It gets chilly at night time, but the room is actually still quite warm so if you do keep the window open, the ocean roars extremely loudly since the cottages are so close to the shoreline. If you are a light sleeper like I am, maybe bring some earplugs.   For most people, the point of staying here is the access to the beach

Summary Heading: Can't beat the price for the awesome ocean views.
Summary: Wife got us a cottage here. The cottages vary from cabin-like to beach-house so choose wisely. Also, the location is really great if you just want fine dine at Beachcomber, drive a mile or two to get a burger at the shake shack, coffee at Starbucks or pickup a few groceries at Trader Joes. There are also plenty of dining options in Laguna Beach or Costa Mesa..

I stayed at the converted garage "cottage" a few years ago, and was back recently on the beach during an event. I see they still book the beachfront places when there's a scheduled event in front of them without warning. There's the day before and the day of the event for trucks hauling, machinery roaring, workers yelling, dust and truck exhaust, all for the settup. Then the night of the event, there's pounding and so-so music, drunk party people yelling, and announcements over the microphones for hours into the night, right outside your window. Then the following day is for take down, trucks, workers, dust, yelling, exhaust... They shouldn't book without giving guests a fair anaccurate warning about these days and nights. But they continue to. I'm guessing they laugh at the

Summary Heading: Heaven on earth, in an earlier time
Summary: We just enjoyed our first visit to Crystal Cove, staying in the Shell Shack, cottage #2.  This magical place rewinds time to an earlier era, and the cottages make this possible.  There is no TV or wifi, and to our thinking, this is a good thing.  Instead of fiddling with gadgets or parking in front of the tube, we sat on our porch and watched the waves for hours on end, experiencing in slow motion the movements of the sun, the moon and the tides.  All day and all night long, the crashing of the waves lulled us into relaxation and eventually sleep.  Early morning and evening walks afforded a steady stream of photo opps of the fantastic Pacific landscape.  We experienced stunning sunsets and even moonsets, and we were lucky enough to have a full moon for our visit.  The tide was

This was our second stay at the Cottages.  Our first was in cottage #40 on the beach.  This time we stayed at #18 on the bluff.  My husband is handicapped, and the parking for #40 is not at all convenient.  At #18 it is right next to the cottage.  Aside from that, here is what we loved about #18:  the spaciousness, the deck, the view, the daybed in the window nook, convenience to the office next door.  The office also provides good coffee.  The cottage is rustic, but comfortable and clean.  It's just a 5 minute drive north to Corona Del Mar, and 2 minutes south to Trader Joe's and restaurants.   This cottage is reserved for guests who have a handicap sign for their car.

If you're looking for a very basic cottage in one of the most beautiful locations in the world, this is for you. It's good to know that the only provided items in the kitchen are a microwave, refrigerator, toaster, paper plates, plastic forks, knives, spoons, and cups. We brought our own coffee maker and cups although coffee is available in the office from 7am. If you can't live without TV or wifi, this is not the place for you! Also, even though some of the cottages accommodate up to 8 people, there is 1 bathroom. If you're looking for a hotel with all the amenities, look elsewhere! This is heaven on earth if you want to read, relax, and have amazing views with the sound of waves all night.

Just love love love this place. It’s so special. Each cottage is different and unique. My goal is to stay in all of them at least once. We stayed in 29B multiple times. It’s perfect for four, with an outstanding patio and panoramic ocean view. Try it, You’ll like it!

We Love Crystal Cove! We have visited many times; however, this was our second overnight visit. The beach and the cottages are magical. We stayed in the Beachcomber Cottage (38) October 15-18, 2013, Room C, and loved it! The room is small and simple, furnished with only a double bed and a small dresser. It has one window which we left open so that we could hear the wonderful ocean music and feel the cool breeze. The Beachcomber is a dorm style cottage. There are 5 various size bedrooms that share 2 full baths, 2 half baths, an extra shower, a kitchen with floor to ceiling windows and 2 decks. It sits atop a bluff, just above the beach and water. We really enjoyed the dorm style experience and met some great people!

Summary Heading: Heavenly Beach in SoCal - Crystal Cove Dive Shack #27
Summary: I still have sand in my toes - we just came home after a wonderful weekend at Crystal Cove, after staying in the Dive Shack (#27).  Very simple, rusting cottage, perfect for reconnecting with family and friends.  Unplugged, ate every meal in our cottage (we brought portable barbecue and camping stove) did puzzles, played games, walked on the beach!  If you need luxury and amenities, this isn't the spot for you.  If you need to fall asleep to the sound of the crashing waves, want time away from cars and hassles, and want to wear your flipflops all the time, this is your place.  Where else can you walk along the beach for 3 miles, without parking lots, cars, and loads of people?  No radio noise, just the sound of the gulls and the waves.  Obviously, still feeling blissful.    This

We stayed during the weekend of 9/20/13. Steven was very helpful with us when checking in. In the back patio, you can bring a small propane gas bbq to cook your food. We ate out during or two nights stay here. We drove to Trader Joe's, which was less than 1 mile away, to buy some snacks.   Painter's Cottage is a cute cottage. We had 6 adults and one baby. The day-bed was perfect for the baby & mom to look out at the view when they couldn't come out. The beds were comfortable. The shower head had very strong pressure. The bathroom sink (cold faucet) could use a little fixing since it kept on turning when we turned on the water.  I originally booked this cottage for 8 people, but since I was not able to fill the occupancy, Reserve America refunded me some money for the two people

Having written a 5 star review after a previous stay, I want to update with a couple of yellow flags. First, as has been noted here, prices increased by 20% this year. With the 10% local hotel tax added in, many cottages get into the $250/night range -- and they are still booked solid and hard to reserve. The good news is that we were told all of the increase is going into the fund for Phase III restoration, which should nearly double the number of rental cottages when it is completed in a number of years.  Second caution is that you should be wary of the "special event venue" stars on the cottage map. These are available for rental, evidently controlled by the restaurant. Two of our four days were impacted by setup for 2 Nissan events for 100+ right under our windows. While

We have stayed many times usually through cancelations. We have stayed in 19A, 19B, 29A, 39B & C, 38C, 2, 24, 27, 32, and recently 45. I have been able to visit a friend for the day in 1. Obviously we love it there and live locally. You have to accept that it is very RUSTIC and the price has continued to increased through the years. I admit I don't like sharing bathrooms and prefer the singular houses. But people we have met in the houses have always been nice. We had fun in 45 in August 2013(more for a couple or with small children) but it was noisy till midnight at least one night and 11:00 PM the next. We also liked 24(July 2013) but had someone water plants in the yard outside bedroom window before 8:00 in the morning. Felt like total lack of privacy and since we were only

We stayed at cottage 40. We really liked the place but our experience with the staff, more specifically with Tom, was terrible. While we were checking in we mentioned to Tom that we would need help carrying our luggage, a service is offered for free, as announced in their web site. He told us to drive down to the Historic District and to call him back to request the shuttle. We parked and called him back in two minutes and called, and called for an hour but no answer. He left us stranded. My wife made 5 trips to carry our luggage to the cottage. In one of them, Tom passed by, while my wife was carrying the luggage, my wife called him but he decided to ignore her. Finally, after a couple of hours I was able to reach Tom, he said he was busy and that he was sorry. I told him he

You will be hard-pressed to find a location along the coast of California that is more scenic than at Crystal Cove.  Located just north of the city of Laguna Beach and south of Newport Beach; this is some of the most valuable beach real estate in the world.  The location couldn't be better.  The cottages themselves, however, will be enjoyed (or not) based on your personal taste and ability to enjoy the rustic beach scene of the 1930's.  They were restored and are maintained to have the charm of yesteryear with few modern conveniences.  It's not exactly camping but it's lightyears away from staying at a Ritz-Carleton.  It is a great location for a summer escape with the family or maybe a couples get-a-way if you can live without TV and the internet for a few days.  Also, it's

I love to go here. Its relaxing.  NO TV - pure family time, beach day either rain or shine, any season is awesome. friendly staff, beautiful views. Its refurnished cabins from the past and many more to be redone . Great history, restuarant is pricey. Ive been to the cottages and dorms. I will stay at either.  I have 2 more trips this summer . I cant wait. My son perfers staying her to a hotel with a TV. Thats so cool. Try the tidepools in winter. At low tide I saw a starfish.  Great place to go!!!

Summary Heading: Loved Falling Asleep to the Sound of the Ocean
Summary: We are a family of 4 and we stayed in 39A, a shared dorm cottage on the cliff. This room is a good size and I loved the huge windows with the amazing ocean view. This cottage has a wonderful deck overlooking the ocean, perfect for reading and spotting dolphins. We shared a bathroom with 39B. FYI 39B is a much smaller room than 39A. Some people don't like sharing a space with other travelers, but we have always met really nice, cool, interesting people. It has never been a problem, on the contrary, we have enjoyed meeting them. The beach was great for long walks, and the water great for swimming. The night we arrived, there was an educational movie on the beach about the grunion run. We had such a good time!   My only negative comment is that I wish  the restaurant there had some

Summary Heading: Tour the Cottages and hear the History of these special cottages
Summary: The second Saturday of the month, there is a free tour offered.  Our 'tour' guide was Laura who lived in these cottages with her family.  She is the driving force that saved these cottages.  She had lots of 'stories' to tell us.  We also were able to go inside several of the cottages.  The tour was excellent.    The cottages are available to stay in, but the reservations are very hard to get and the cottages do not have modern conveniences as they have restored them back to the old days.  You get a micro and a frig, but no stove.  The cottages themselves are 'rough'.  You might do tour first, if you are interested in staying here.  The views are great though.  The public can picnic on the beach and on the deck outside the check in cottage.  Parking for the day is $15.00, it is

I love staying here. It is so peaceful. A real throwback to another generation. No cars, great views. Beautiful walks on the beach. The accommodations vary. I also take my sleeping bag and just throw it on the bed not even bothering to make the beds with their bedding. No inside stove, a grill outside instead. A basic sized microwave though. Trader Joes is about 3/4 of a mile south in a shopping center so you can always walk over there and stock up on some of their prepared foods. Restaurant is overpriced and the food is mediocre. Breakfast is good there. We have been lucky to stay twice. Would go back in a heart beat. If you are in the area, stop in at the"office" and check 'em out. During the winter they have a beautiful Christmas tree on the sand.

Quaint, dirty, crowded, rude, and who cares?  This is a bad idea, poorly executed. Trying to preserve decaying buildings on the beach is a losing proposition and ultimately unsustainable.  We had the absolute worst cabin, #45!  Terrible doesn't do the "experience" justice.   The "Emperor" has no clothes.  Starting with a rude check in clerk to a dirty cabin to a bad "restaurant"' this was a bad two days.   This is park is an indulgence of well meaning idiots.  Don't stay here.

We snagged 38C, the tiniest room available but it has a small ocean-view window.  The bed is okay for a friendly couple.  The sound of the ocean at night is wonderful.  Beware that the room is between two bathrooms so you can hear a lot of flushing.  But for $65 a night, nothing compares.

My parents booked Cottage #18 (Sunset Bungalow) for my dad's 80th Birthday Slumber Party.  They happened by chance the week before to get a one night cancellation in Cottage #18 which is a designated ADA handicap bungalow (you must show proof with handicap placard).  Sitting high atop the bluff, the views of the ocean were magnifcent.  After reading reviews of all of the rules and restrictions I was expecting some difficuties in getting to the cottage, registering or other rules as listed.  But in fact, it couldn't have been easier.  I flew in from Michigan to surprise my dad and I did.  My two sisters and I shared the cottage with my parent's and had a wonderful time.  Besides the one bedroom, there is a trundle twin bed in a windows-all- round porch with awesome views of the

Once you turn off the highway - a smile overcomes your face.  You check in and are taken to your cabin.  Turn your watch back to the 50s and relax. Sit on your deck - watch the ebb and flow of the ocean and allow the crashing of the waves to soothe your nerves. This is a place where less is more. Wooden benches- creaky floors and helps to strip away what is urgent.  It helps to remember what is important.

This is our third stay at the Crystal Cove Beach cottages.  This time, we were lucky to have #16 The Sand Castle.  We arrived at 4:15 and were third in line for the electric cart that takes you and your belongings to the cottage--some people seemed to have checked in early though.  As others have mentioned, logistics are a little complicated, but read everything on the website about what to expect and make sure you understand that a stay here is more like luxury camping in a historic district than a resort.  The Sand Castle has large rooms, including a room with full-size bed up a steep narrow staircase with windows on three sides and glorious views (and very clean windows!).  There's a inside dining table with seven chairs, decorated shelves, second bedroom, sleeper sofa, bar

We love this beach, and the cottages are a nice option. But you really need to check the individual cottages before you book, especially if you care about privacy for you and your children, or if you like to read or work or whatever in bed. Some first floor "cottages" are little more than tiny converted garage-type rooms and are fishbowls. Beach passers-by have full view of you/your family relaxing or in bed when you have the window open, from sunset until sunrise in summer--when you need the window open. Yes, there's a view, and your window does face the ocean, but you don't get much of the view from these rooms, or everyone has a view of you.   And be very, very careful about fund raisers and other events that might be happening when you're planning your trip, as all the

Me and my GF stayed here a few weeks back. I was able to secure a reservation thru Reserve.America @ the last minute due to a vacancy. For $65 we had our own beach front cottage with a million dollar view. The room was 39B (double bunk bed) witch is a longboard cottage themed in classic Hawaii island flair. The kitchen and common area was very clean and well taken care of. The furniture and bedding was clean and gave us no excuses. See I didn't care if we had to sleep on bunk beds, Crystal Cove Cottages are 7 month out and I wasn't going to put our two year anniversary on hold. We had a great time walking around and enjoying the beachside and views. THIS place looks like you walked into a time warp!!! The biggest downside was the cost of my Jack&Diet ($9) but the drink was

I felt very lucky to finally be able to reserve a cottage after trying for three months. We reserved the "Shell Shack" cottage #2. It's located right next to the Beachcomber Cafe. It's really one big room with two murphy beds, a day bed and a couch that pulls out into a bed. The Bathroom was clean and nice. The view out the front is unbeatable. The beautiful beach and ocean, right outside your door. There was a little bit of noise from the restaraunt but nothing too disturbing. Just be ready for lots of activity, golf carts park right infront of the cottage and the bottom floor is used by the restaraunt. The beach is beautiful and the feel of the whole area is so neat. Very historic. We ate at the Cafe three times and it was good. I thought the breakfast offerings were the best,

I have book a cottage for next week.  I live locally and found a cancellation so I grabbed it.  If you cannot check into your room until 4pm but they are kicking you out at 11am what happens to the room between then?  It takes them 5 hours to clean the room?  Can I hang out at the beach before I get into my room?  Just curious, since we are only staying 1 night we wanted to get in as much as we can.

We stayed in Cottage 40 - it is a cottage reserved for disabled guests.  The cottage was recently refirb'd and was in very good shape, and I was happy to find that is was very clean. The deck is amazing - large, mostly private and right on the sand! The "kitchen" has a half fridge, the smallest sink I have ever seen and a microwave. We brought a propane camp stove (used on the deck), so with that we had everything we needed to eat-in during our time there. The bathroom was very large and well layed out.The sunsets were beautiful and the sound of the frogs at night was enjoyable... so loud (still not sure if it was really frogs or a recording, seemed strange that they stopped at the same time each night all at the same time).  The folks that work there were very informative about

Everyones' reviews are spot on.  The cottages are vintage (ok, funky too) at best, no working kitchen,  Bring your own Coleman Stove and cooking supplies (pots, utensils, etc), prepare for a small. uncomfortale bed and the unfriendl front desk workers who are not the most accomodating.....   BUT you cannot beat the location and price.  Makes for a one of a kind vacation.  Fall asleep to the waves - wake up to an empty coastline and dolphins playing in the waves. The panoramic ocean views are really unbeatable, especially for the price.  Yes, the whole parking situation is not ideal, but you can work around this.  Shuttles run frequently and this whole parking situation keeps the beach less crowded.  The cottages are like taking a step back in time - to the old-time surf movies.

I hope the folks at Crystal Cove Cabins read this. I have very mixed feelings about this place. First, what I love -  The beauty of the coast can't be beat, the cabins are cool and funky but the staff experience kills it. We have stayed numerous times over the years but whenever I book there,  I prepare myself for a daily dose uncomfortable interactions with the staff.  I have felt scrutinized, questioned and a suspect of one sort or another. Issues have been, questions about who exactly is in your party, frantic calls if you are one minute late at check-out and more.  Definitely a police-state mentality. It can cost about 200$ a night plus additional for extra people. But, the beauty of the place draws me back.  Be prepared to know you will be nowhere near your car.

Since readers seem to find my Crystal Cove Cottage reviews helpful for the descriptions of individual cottages, here is another one. I'm writing it as I sit in cottage 45, the Soda Shack. For more information about the cottages in general, read my previous reviews. If you think of a visit to Crystal Cove as very comfortable camping, you are likely to have a one-of-a-kind experience and a great time.    The Soda Shack was once home to an ice cream and soda fountain. Now it serves as an individual cottage for guests to rent. It recently became the 12th individual cottage for rent, increasing your odds of getting one just a wee bit more: http://www.kcet.org/socal/socal_wanderer/accommodations/crystal-cove-opens-new-cottage.html  Aside from historic photos on the wall, little

Summary Heading: One night stay not worth it
Summary: My husband, 2 kids and I stayed in cottage 38B on a whim while on a vacation in S. California. I knew how difficult it was to get one of these so when I saw one available on a date that worked for us, I rather impulsively grabbed it. Problem was that check-in was at 4 pm and check-out at 11 am, and they are real sticklers about this, even advising you to be packed and ready to go at 10:30 am. Didn't give us much time to enjoy the cottage and deck area. With an additional fee of about $11 they tack on at checkout, our total cost was about $130. For such a limited stay, this hurt. I am just glad to have done it, and experienced a neat piece of history, so no complaints there but overall this was too expensive for what we got. My kids are 8 and 5 so we were charged extra person

We got a last-minute chance to stay at cottage number 24, a great location perched up several flights of stairs, just down from the Beachcomber Restaurant. So far, so great. As these reservations are hard to come by, we took over a friend's who couldn't come. So we were willing to roll with the punches. First, let me say it was like vacationing in a Communist country. The desk workers were, well, not surly, but extremely reluctant to do anything more than scrape-by bare minimum. First, only one check-in ride on the golf cart per cottage---even if you have a baby and two different families on the list, like we did!
